newsitem.title: USA: US OPTIONS FOCUS/Investors snap up Sunglass Hut.
newsitem.headline: US OPTIONS FOCUS/Investors snap up Sunglass Hut.

text.p: Investors were buying options on shares of Sunglass Hut International Inc Thursday, as the stock rallied after the company posted a 7.8 percent increase in July same store sales.
"Sales came in better-than-expected," said John Colletti, a market maker in Sunglass Hut options at the Chicago Board Options Exchange. "I've had customers buying options all day long."
By 1400 CDT/1900 GMT, Sunglass Hut was up 1-9/16 at 10 on solid turnover of 7.5 million shares.

In addition to the same store sales increse, the sunglasses retailer said its inventory levels were cut to $115 million from $145 million since the beginning of the year and its revolving debt borrowings were paid back in full by the end of the second quarter.
Montgomery Securities upgraded the stock to buy from hold and Colletti said the upgrade was probably a main factor driving the stock higher.
The company reminded investors that its ongoing plan to reduce and refresh inventory levels was expected to cut gross margins in the second quarter and the rest of the year.
Among the Sunglass Hut options, the December 10 call was most active, with volume of 2,190 contracts. The option, which had open interest of 388 contracts, gained 3/4 to 1-5/8.
The September 10 call traded 1,440 contracts. It rose 11/16 to 1.0 and had open interest of 1,246.
Other active calls included the September 7-1/2 and March 10, which traded 755 and 540 contracts, respectively.
The busiest Sunglass Hut put was the December 7-1/2, which traded about 85 contracts.
Colletti said volatility in the options was up about five percentage points to the 68 to 70 percent level.

In other trading, Apple Computer Inc options remained busy as the stock extended its sharp Wednesday gains on optimism the $150 million cash injection from Microsoft Corp and a new board of directors will help the company.
The stock was up 2-3/4 at 29-1/16 after reaching 29-3/4, a level not seen since late February 1996. Volume continued heavy, topping 31.4 million shares.
The August 30 calls were the most popular, with turnover of about 7,375 contracts, but activity in both puts and calls was strong through the January series.

The January 30, September 30 and October 30 calls drew the most interest among the calls. Put activity was led by the August 27-1/2 and 30, which traded 2,675 and 2,465 contracts, respectively. The January 25 and 27-1/2 and the September 25 puts also were fairly active.
Options on a couple other technology stocks were also active, including Compaq Computer Corp on the Pacific Exchange.
Compaq calls were particularly active as the stock rallied 3-3/4 to 62-3/8. The September 65 call traded 5,600 contracts.
